fields.Title of Contribution: <p>Mental Health Factors: Stress, Loneliness, and Academic Performance in Domestic vs. International College Students</p>
fields.Journal: Boston Congress of Public Health Review
fields.Description/Abstract: <p>Background<br>College students, particularly international students, face unique challenges related to<br>mental health and academic performance. Previous studies have shown that stress,<br>loneliness and psychological distress significantly impact both domestic and<br>international students, but the extent and predictors of these issues may vary between<br>groups.<br>Methods<br>Data were drawn from 102,905 respondents in the 2022 American College Health<br>Association’s National College Health Assessment, including 89,663 domestic and 13,242<br>international students. A cross-sectional secondary analysis using logistic regression<br>examined associations between stress and variables such as loneliness, psychological<br>distress, and academic outcomes.<br>Results<br>Stress significantly predicted loneliness, psychological distress, and educational<br>challenges in both groups. International students had slightly higher odds of<br>experiencing loneliness (AOR = 1.508) and academic distress (AOR = 4.467) than domestic<br>students.<br>Discussion<br>The findings of this study underscore the importance of understanding the distinct<br>mental health challenges faced by domestic and international college students.<br>Conclusion<br>Tailored mental health interventions and social integration initiatives are essential to<br>addressing the unique challenges of international students and promoting their well-being and academic success.</p>
